title: Module Imports
description: Different ways to import modules and functions.

cards.front: How do you import an entire module?
cards.back: Use 'import module_name': import math - then access with math.function()

cards.front: How do you import specific functions from a module?
cards.back: Use 'from module import function': from math import sqrt - then use sqrt() directly
This imports all functions from a module into the current namespace. It's generally discouraged due to potential naming conflicts.

cards.front: How do you give a module an alias?
cards.back: Use 'import module as alias': import numpy as np - then use np.function()

cards.front: Where does Python look for modules?
cards.back: Python searches in the current directory, then in directories listed in sys.path, including the standard library.

cards.front: What happens when you import a module?
cards.back: Python executes the module code and creates a module object in sys.modules
Yes: try: import optional_module except ImportError: pass
Standard library module for dynamic importing: importlib.import_module('mymodule')

cards.front: How do you reload a module?
cards.back: import importlib; importlib.reload(module) - useful for development
Built-in function for importing modules dynamically, but importlib is preferred

title: Python Standard Library
description: Essential modules that come with Python.

cards.back: Operating system interface: file operations, directory handling, environment variables.
System-specific parameters and functions: command line arguments, Python path, exit functions.

cards.front: What is the 'math' module used for?
cards.back: Mathematical functions: sqrt(), sin(), cos(), pi, e constants, logarithms, etc.
Random number generation: randint(), choice(), shuffle(), random() for floats between 0 and 1.
Date and time manipulation: creating dates, calculating differences, formatting timestamps.
High-performance container datatypes: Counter, defaultdict, deque, namedtuple.
JSON encoding/decoding: json.dumps(), json.loads(), json.dump(), json.load().
Regular expressions: re.match(), re.search(), re.findall(), re.sub().
Functions creating iterators for efficient looping: chain, cycle, repeat, combinations.
Higher-order functions: partial, lru_cache, reduce, wraps.
Object-oriented filesystem paths: Path objects instead of string paths.
Command-line argument parsing: creating user-friendly CLI interfaces.
Flexible logging system: debug, info, warning, error, critical levels.
Unit testing framework: TestCase, assert methods, test discovery.
SQLite database interface: connect, cursor, execute, commit.

title: Creating Modules
description: How to write and organize your own modules.

cards.front: How do you create a Python module?
cards.back: Create a .py file with functions, classes, or variables - filename becomes module name
__name__ is '__main__' when module runs directly, module name when imported

cards.front: How do you make code run only when module is executed directly?
cards.back: Use if __name__ == '__main__': block for scripts
Defines what gets imported with 'from module import *'

cards.front: How do you document a module?
cards.back: Add module docstring at the top of the file
Code that runs when module is imported - use sparingly

cards.front: How do you handle module initialization?
cards.back: Put initialization code at module level or in functions
Contains the module's file path

cards.front: How do you create module constants?
cards.back: Use UPPERCASE names: MAX_SIZE = 100
Global scope within the module file
Directory containing __init__.py and modules - can be imported as a unit
Makes directory a package, can contain initialization code and __all__

cards.front: How do you import from a package?
cards.back: from package import module or from package.module import function
Nested packages: package.subpackage.module

cards.front: How do you create a package structure?
cards.back: Create directory with __init__.py and module files
Package without __init__.py - allows split packages across directories

cards.front: How do you use relative imports?
cards.back: from . import module (same package) or from .. import module (parent package)

cards.front: When should you use relative imports?
cards.back: Within packages to avoid hardcoding package names
Full path from top-level package: from mypackage.subpackage import module

cards.front: How do you handle circular imports?
cards.back: Move imports inside functions, use importlib, or restructure code
Python package installer: pip install package_name

cards.front: How do you install a specific version?
cards.back: pip install package==1.2.3 or pip install 'package>=1.0.0'
File listing package dependencies with versions
pip freeze > requirements.txt or manually list dependencies
Isolated Python environment for project dependencies

cards.front: How do you create a virtual environment?
cards.back: python -m venv myenv or virtualenv myenv

cards.front: How do you activate virtual environment?
cards.back: Windows: myenv\Scripts\activate, Unix: source myenv/bin/activate
Package manager for Python and other languages, includes virtual environments
Python Package Index - central repository for Python packages
pip install --upgrade pip
Tools for managing requirements: pip-compile, pip-sync

cards.front: How do you install from GitHub?
cards.back: pip install git+https://github.com/user/repo.git
Modern Python packaging and dependency management tool
Python dependency management tool combining pip and virtualenv

cards.front: How do you check installed packages?
cards.back: pip list or pip show package_name

title: Import Best Practices
description: Guidelines for clean and efficient imports.

cards.back: No, it pollutes namespace and can cause name conflicts
Standard library, third-party, local modules - separated by blank lines
Yes within packages, but absolute imports are clearer

cards.front: What is import aliasing best practice?
cards.back: Use standard aliases: import numpy as np, import pandas as pd

cards.front: Should you import modules or specific functions?
cards.back: Import what you need - specific functions if you use few, whole module if many

cards.front: How do you handle optional dependencies?
cards.back: Try-except import blocks with informative error messages
Import modules inside functions to reduce startup time
Yes, they indicate poor design - restructure to eliminate them

cards.front: How do you import for type hints?
cards.back: Use TYPE_CHECKING: from typing import TYPE_CHECKING; if TYPE_CHECKING: import heavy_module
Time taken to import modules - optimize by importing only what's needed

title: Module Search Path
description: How Python finds and loads modules.

cards.back: List of directories Python searches for modules

cards.front: How do you add to sys.path?
cards.back: sys.path.append('/path/to/modules') or sys.path.insert(0, '/path')
Colon-separated list of directories added to sys.path
Directory where pip installs third-party packages
Files containing paths to add to sys.path
Dictionary of loaded modules: module_name -> module_object
Compiled .pyc files in __pycache__ directories
Environment variable that removes docstrings and assertions
Custom importers that can load modules from non-standard sources
Allows importing modules from ZIP archives
Numerical computing library with N-dimensional arrays
Data manipulation and analysis library with DataFrame
Plotting library for creating visualizations
HTTP library for making web requests
Web frameworks: Flask (micro), Django (full-featured)
Testing framework with fixtures and plugins
SQL toolkit and Object-Relational Mapping (ORM)
Machine learning library for Python
Deep learning frameworks for neural networks
Interactive computing environment with notebooks
Script defining package metadata and dependencies
Modern configuration file for Python projects (PEP 518)
Configuration file for setup.py with package metadata

cards.front: How do you build a distribution?
cards.back: python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel or python -m build

cards.front: What is wheel vs source distribution?
cards.back: Wheel: pre-built, faster install; Source: requires compilation
File specifying additional files to include in distribution

cards.front: How do you upload to PyPI?
cards.back: Use twine: twine upload dist/*

cards.front: What is version control for packages?
cards.back: Use semantic versioning: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH
Define console scripts in setup.py for command-line tools
Tools for creating standalone executables from Python scripts

title: Module Execution
description: How modules are executed and loaded.

cards.front: What happens when you run 'python module.py'?
cards.back: __name__ is set to '__main__', module code executes

cards.front: What is the module execution order?
cards.back: 1. Find module, 2. Compile to bytecode, 3. Execute, 4. Create module object
Python compiles .py to .pyc files for faster loading
Directory containing compiled bytecode files

cards.front: Can you run modules without .py extension?
cards.back: Yes, if in ZIP archive or other importable location
python -m module runs module as script: __name__ = '__main__'
#!/usr/bin/env python3 - allows direct execution on Unix
Special file in packages that runs when package executed with -m

cards.front: How do you handle module cleanup?
cards.back: Use try-finally or atexit.register() for cleanup functions
Forcing re-execution of module code during development
